subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] Re: Door to the Dead
author: Larry Weinreich
full_text:
------=_NextPart_000_0249_01C99147.71E6DAB0
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Knock once for yes and twice for no.

  ----- Original Message ----- 
  Fro=
m: Golden Phoenix 
  To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups.com 
  Sent: Tuesday, February=
 17, 2009 7:34 PM
  Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] Re: Door to the Dead


        Y=
es but we dont have to hide and sneak around like the good old days when pe=
ople didnt even want to think about spirits and so forth. Now we need fancy=
 expensive equipment to be taken seriously. 35 mm was my camera of choice f=
or many man years. cassette tape was as good as it got for audio thyen vhs =
cameras came in but low light slowed things down with them till the advent =
of fancy new fangled night vision and so forth the old infra red was as goo=
d as it got 30-40 years ago. god I am getting old.LOL

        http://www.m=
yspace.com/ghost_hunter50 see my site links

        --- On Tue, 2/17/09, J=
ohn S <phenom_investigator@...> wrote:


          From: John S <phen=
om_investigator@...>
          Subject: [EVP-ITC] Re: Door to the Dea=
d
          To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups.com
          Date: Tuesday, February 1=
7, 2009, 6:53 PM


          It is truly ironic that part of my professiona=
l background and training happens to be in broadcast production. So I am in=
timately aware of what it takes to produce and distribute television progra=
ms and why and how this is done. I concur completely that it is inaccurate =
to view these shows as "reality". They are of course "entertainment. " (Act=
ually they have their own classification which came into being a few years =
ago.)

          What is troubling, perhaps only to me because of my backgr=
ound, is that such shows have come to represent to the public the state of =
affairs in this and related fields. The more investment there the more this=
 is obvious.
